title: â€˜Not for mineâ€™: Cats T-shirts divide AFL world
text:
Geelong unveils new T-shirt playing strip for 2017 JLT Community Series against Hawthorn February 17, 2017 8:49pm by Staff Writers Source: FOX SPORTS AT FIRST glance, youâ€™d be excused for thinking Hawthorn had gatecrashed a Geelong training session when the Cats graced the University of Tasmania Stadium turf on Friday night. 
But nope, this was for real. 
The Cats unveiled their new â€” and very unique â€” pre-season playing strip for 2017 in Launceston on Friday night. 
As part of the Catsâ€™ new apparel partnership with Cotton On, they donned an AFL-first â€œrugby-styledâ€ jumper, which was a skin-tight T-shirt with a V-neck cut. 
A few traditional blue hoops were printed across the chest, but the most notable aspect of the jumper was the capital G plastered across the torso. 
Western Bulldogs legend Brad Johnson, who spent a few weeks coaching the Cats over the summer, said he was a fan of the new look. 
â€œI like them, I think they look very good,â€ Johnson told Fox Footy . Patrick Dangerfield in Geelongâ€™s new-look jumper. Source: Getty Images 
â€œTheyâ€™ve got a new sponsor in Cotton On for their active range, so itâ€™s great theyâ€™ve jumped on board.â€ 
Hawthorn champion Dermott Brereton, however, wasnâ€™t so impressed. 
â€œI like symmetry in the jumper. A â€˜Gâ€™ doesnâ€™t have many symmetrical notions,â€ Brereton said. 
â€œSorry, not for mine.â€ 
But Fox Footy caller Dwayne Russell, who played 50 VFL games in the blue and white hoops, was in Johnsonâ€™s corner. 
â€œIf youâ€™re a 45-year-old, youâ€™re not going to be walking the streets in a footy jumper. But you might wear a T-shirt,â€ Russell said. 
â€œI like it, you can wear it around the streets and itâ€™s not too crazy.â€

Geelongâ€™s decision to go down the T-shirt path mirrors what many NBA teams are now doing, switching between traditional singlets and sleeved jerseys.
